It was during these formative years that he began to develop his diagnostic acumen and hone his clinical skills. Following medical school, Dr. Malekzadeh embarked on his residency training, a period of intense clinical immersion where he gained hands-on experience in the diagnosis and treatment of a wide array of medical conditions. This training likely involved rotations through various medical departments, including internal medicine, surgery, and critical care, providing him with a comprehensive understanding of the complexities of human health. It was during his internal medicine residency that his interest in the complexities of the digestive system solidified, leading him to pursue a fellowship in gastroenterology.

The gastroenterology fellowship represented a further deepening of his expertise, allowing him to focus exclusively on the diagnosis and management of disorders affecting the esophagus, stomach, small intestine, colon, rectum, pancreas, liver, and biliary system. This intensive training involved mastering advanced diagnostic and therapeutic procedures, such as endoscopy, colonoscopy, liver biopsy, and motility studies. He would have been exposed to a wide range of gastrointestinal conditions, including inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), peptic ulcer disease, gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), liver cirrhosis, and gastrointestinal cancers. His fellowship training would have also emphasized the importance of evidence-based medicine, critical thinking, and patient-centered care – principles that would guide his practice throughout his career.
